title.narrative: Swedac, ATU - Agadir Techn. Unit phase 2, 2014-19
Swedac, ATU - Agadir Techn. Unit phase 2, 2014-19

description.narrative: Harmonisering av tekniska regler, ömsesidigt godkända tekniska handelsstrukturer och marknadskontroll
Harmonized technical regulations, conformity assessment procedures and market survellience

Systems and structures are nationally and regionally implemented to use for harmonising mandatory requirements (technical regulations), voluntary standards and enforcement of national mandatory requirements, in order to bring down technical barriers to trade.

participating-org.narrative: SWEDAC/Styrelsen för ackreditering och teknisk kontroll
SWEDAC/Styrelsen för ackreditering och teknisk kontroll

description.narrative:
THE AGADIR TECHNICHAL UNIT (ATU) is the regional organization responsible for managing the Agadir process and works as the Secretariat for the Agreement. The main task of the ATU is to follow up the implementation of Agadir Agreement. The overall objective of the programme is to support the economic integration process among Agadir countries provided by Agadir Agreement thus (i) boosting trade, (ii) increasing economic development and (iii) attracting Forign Direct lnvestment. This is also hoped to contribute to poverty reduction and increased economic independence of the four member states. On of the main aim of the ATU programme has been the harmonization of technical regulations, which is one of the main cornerstones in interregional trade between the Agadir countries. This harmonizationshall take place between the relevant authorities in the countries such asministries and regulatory authorities. Harmonization of voluntary standards between the Agadir counties is at the same time of importance to further trade in the region. This harmonization is to takeplace between the national standards bodies in line with the principles laid down in the WTO agreements and the EU practices. The Progarm is seeking to achieve the following outcomes and outputs:a) Ensuring an agreed common approach among the member states of Agadir Agreement regarding harmonized technical regulations, conformity assessment procedures, standards and market suweillance procedures. Results were satisfactory. To increase awareness among Agadir member country officials concerning the need to enhance efforts to remove technical barriers to trade according to the Agadir agreement, an information strategy for the communication and promotional activities for Agadir Agreement purposes wasdeveloped and included within the ATU strategic plan that was finalised in2017. In the future, this will enable individual activities to be “joined-up” within a cohesive strategy that relates to the long-term operation of the ATU. This strategy included: - Press releases to be provided on all events, meetings, seminars and workshops organized by ATU or in which the ATU takes part. These are published in daily newspapers and specialized magazines in the 4 countries in 3 languages. This is also extended to the website and other social media forms. - The ATU hiring an IT expert/consultant in 2018 to support the ATU and the Member States in implementing the electronic system for sharing information on harmonized products.- Trade data and other relevant information following each event or meeting being communicated and the output from Agadir workshops being shared with the countries and key stakeholders.- Promotional activities to be organised by the ATU on a yearly basis to promote the Agadir Agreement, and to communicate its achievements and the results made b) Harmonized legal framework for technical regulations guided by EU legal framework and harmonized systems and structures. Results were satisfactory. The programme supported the development of the managerial structures between the countries and ATU, and also the procedures and methods for the operation of the National Focal Points (NFPs) to ensure that the harmonisation processes progressed well and that the operations of the NFPs were performed in an effective and efficient way. This included but was not limited to: - Procedures to initiate the responsibilities of harmonising the different sectoral laws and allocate and transmit them to the other Members. - Procedures for the responsible organisations to participate in the harmonisation work - Operating the national parts of the databases to be established to support the harmonisation work - Being the extended arm of the managerial structures of ATU - Coordinating feedback within timeline of an activity - Proposing organisational and managerial structures and methodologies - Developing a budget proposal for the costs necessary for the adjusted organisation beyond the end of the programme
c) Harmonized conformity assessment procedures according to the internationally accepted best practices. Results were not 100 % satisfactorydue to delay to start the programme in this field. The study on technical barriers to trade/baseline report was not started until December 2014. In retrospect, this activityshould have been completed much earlier (perhaps as part of Phase 1 of the overall Agadir project) in order to inform better the direction that Phase 2 should take and determine the key motivation for the programme. Although the ATU had similar broad information from previous studies, the data needed to be updated urgently in order to formulate and agree a priority product list from which selected products areas could be chosen. As these were to be used as the basis for Outcomes D, E and F, the delay in the study on technical barriers to trade/baseline report meant that these Outcomes could not start until 2015, although it did not delay the development of the necessary systems and procedures that in any case needed to be put in place.
d) The adoption of international standards by the national standardizationbodies in the four member states. Results were satisfactory. Work on this activity started in May 2015 with an initial workshop focusing on creating a methodology for harmonizing mandatory requirements on selected products areas based on the priority product list agreed by the Agadircountries. It also included discussion on the tools necessary to allow relevant national authorities to initiatediscussion at the national level and was attended by key regulatory and policy makers as well as specialists from the four Agadir Countries. This was followed by programme experts visiting each Agadir country to help develop national positions regarding ways to establish the necessary systems and structures for technical harmonization, in preparation for establishing the final consensus among the countries. A second regional workshop in November 2015 focused on Good Regulatory Practice (GRP) and Regulatory Impact Assessments (RIA). The main focus of the workshop was on consumer product safety legislation applied in all the countries and specific provisions of national legislation on general product safety in each country. Regulatory agencies especially in the field of product safety and consumer goods, and staff working with preparing regulations as well as the national TBT notification and contact points, participated. An interesting finding coming from the representatives of the regulatory authorities seemed to lead to the main conclusion that there are no burdensome TBTs that were identified and that administrations in the participatingcountries have not shown any demand for comprehensive regional harmonization efforts. This was in spite of the fact that at the beginning of the programme, the prerequisites for technical harmonization in the region were clearly communicated and that in order to harmonize, there must be a clear demand for a harmonization process. This does not necessarily reflect that systems and structures for harmonizing mandatory requirements are not needed in the region. Eventual barriers and possibilities for improvements for intra-Agadir trade can only be confirmed if structured and shared processes are developed for GRP and RIA. In other words, processes may reveal differences in regulatory practices and requirements for industrial products. However, it is also crucial to keep in mind that systems and structures for technical harmonization require very strong national drivers and coordination. The same goes for regional harmonization efforts. At the time of the workshops, it was clear that the participating countries had differentpriorities and different interests in technical harmonization. Two further regional workshops were held in 2018 as the final step within the framework of the programme Outcome D, to provide participants with the means and technical tools to be used by the regulatory authorities and to enhance the discussion on information sharing regarding mandatory technical requirements. The focus was activating Article 23 of the Agadir Agreement and the output was to agree on transparency mechanisms in the regulation processes and coordination on national level while enacting technical regulation. In order for the notification procedure to fulfil its purpose of increasing transparency, avoiding technical barriers to trade and creating opportunities for regional harmonisation for the Agadir countries in the future the Programme achieved a consensus on ATU guideline for GRP and RIA, and a template for notification according to Agadir Agreement’ Article 23.
e) Providing harmonized market suweillance procedures Results were satisfactory. - The IT platform necessary to support the programme and to support the databases and communication facilities to allow a smooth and effective co-operation between the countries to perform harmonization was developed in 2015 and introduced in 2016. Based on commercially available software, it was designed to help all concerned to communicate, collaborate and share information in an effective, secure and transparent manner. As well as providing a flexible solution to meeting the needs of the harmonization processes, it also provides the ATU with a powerful IT platform. By 2017, the IT platform was fully operational. Specific pages had been designed for different products on the platform, and representatives of PWGs had been appointed to manage their pages. Web pages for the pilot product areas were designed with the relevant data for the harmonized standards, technical regulations and conformity assessment procedures inserted. Adesignated page was also created for the private sector, open to the public and to all interested parties, showing procedures, standards, requirements and regulations in force in various countries for all harmonized products. Three intensive training sessions for technicians from the Member States were organised to provide training on access to the platform, data input and updating operations, and on online communication using the IT platform. Representatives from the NFPs have also been trained on the features of the platform. The platform was officially handed over to the ATU in June 2018.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
